qas.question: What is the range of the electromagnetic spectrum in micrometers?
In nanometers, what is the electromagnetic spectrum's range?
What law states that infrared radiation is emitted by objects based on temperature?
What happens to the amount of radiation an object emits as temperature increases?
What type of cameras see infrared radiation?
What camera detects temperature in the infrared range?
What law states that infrared radiation is emitted by objects based on environment?
When an object has visible illumination, what happens to the amount of radiation an object emits?
What is the range of the black body radiation law?
What is the nanometer range that allows you to see temperature variations?

context: <a4_0><b5_0>Thermographic<a4_0/> cameras<b5_0/> detect radiation in the infrared range of the electromagnetic spectrum (roughly <a1_0><b9_0>900–14,000<a1_0/> nanometers<b9_0/> or <a0_0><b8_0>0.9–14<b8_0/><a0_0/> μm) and produce images of that radiation. Since infrared radiation is emitted by all objects based on their temperatures, according to <a2_0><b6_0>the black body radiation law<b6_0/><a2_0/>, thermography makes it possible to "see" one's environment with or without visible illumination. The amount of radiation emitted by an object <a3_0><b7_0>increases<b7_0/><a3_0/> with temperature, therefore thermography allows one to see variations in temperature (hence the name).
